35 Jinja Road
[[Kampala]] |employees = |budget = |chief1_name = '''Dr.Emmanuel Iyamulemye Niyibigira'''{{cite web|date=July 2017 |url=http://ugandacoffee.go.ug/about-us/ |title=The birthplace of Robusta coffee |accessdate=31 May 2016| publisher=The World Folio|author=United World}} |chief1_position =
[[Managing Director]] |parent_agency =Uganda Ministry of Agriculture |website = [http://www.ugandacoffee.go.ug/ Homepage] |footnotes = }} The '''Uganda Coffee Development Authority''' (UCDA) is a government agency mandated to "promote and oversee the [[coffee industry]] by supporting research, promoting production, controlling the quality and improving the marketing of coffee" in the country.{{cite web|accessdate=31 May 2016|last= UCDA| url=http://www.ugandacoffee.go.ug/index.php?page&i=9|title=Uganda Coffee Development Authority: Background - Who We Are |publisher=Uganda Coffee Development Authority (UCDA) |location=Kampala |date=31 May 2016}} ==Location== The headquarters of the agency are located at Coffee House, 35 Jinja Road, in the [[central business district]] of [[Kampala]], the capital and largest city in the country. The coordinates of UCDA headquarters are:0°18'53.0"N, 32°35'28.0"E (Latitude:0.314735; Longitude:32.591106).{{google maps| url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/0%C2%B018'53.0%22N+32%C2%B035'28.0%22E/@0.3147365,32.5904998,125m/data=!3m2!1e3!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x0:0x0!8m2!3d0.314735!4d32.591106 |title=Location of UCDA Headquarters|accessdate=31 May 2016}} ==Overview== UCDA was established in 1991, by government decree. The law was later modifies by parliament in 1994. It is administered under the Uganda Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries.{{cite web|last=UMAAIF | url=http://www.agriculture.go.ug/Agencies/43 |title=The Agencies of the Uganda Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries (UMAAIF) | location=Kampala |accessdate=31 May 2016 |date=31 May 2016}} The agency periodically releases production{{cite web|date=17 December 2015 | url=https://af.reuters.com/article/investingNews/idAFKBN0U013G20151217| title=Uganda coffee exports rise 13 percent in November: UCDA|first=Elias| accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=[[Reuters]] |last= Biryabarema}} and price{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2012-08-30/uganda-coffee-development-authority-s-robusta-prices-table-|first=Fred| title=Uganda Coffee Development Authority’s Robusta Prices|last=Ojambo| date=30 August 2012 |accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=[[Bloomberg.com]]}} data. ==See also== *[[Economy of Uganda]] *[[Agriculture in Uganda]] *[[Ministry of Agriculture, Animal Industry and Fisheries (Uganda)]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.ugandacoffee.go.ug/ Website of Uganda Coffee Development Authority] {{Kampala District}} [[Category:Kampala]] [[Category:Government of Uganda]] [[Category:Economy of Uganda]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1991]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Uganda]] [[Category:Agriculture in Uganda]] [[Category:Kampala Central Division]] [[Category:Coffee industry]]

{{short description|American technology journalist}} {{Infobox person | name = Walt Mossberg | image = Mossbergjobsji1.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Walt Mossberg (''left'') with [[Steve Jobs]] (''right'')
at ''All Things Digital'' 5 in 2007 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1947|03|27}} | birth_place = [[Warwick, Rhode Island]], U.S. | nationality = [[United States|American]] | alma_mater = [[Brandeis University]]
[[Columbia University]] | occupation = Columnist, journalist | spouse = | children = | parents = | website = {{URL|https://www.theverge.com/users/WaltMossberg/posts}}| }} '''Walter S. Mossberg''' (born March 27, 1947) is an [[United States|American]] journalist. He is widely credited with pioneering the modern, consumer-focused, technology review and commentary. From 1991 through 2013, he was the principal technology columnist for ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]''. He also co-founded ''[[AllThingsD]]'', [[Recode.net|''Recode'']] and the [[All Things Digital|D]] and [[Recode|Code Conferences.]] From 2015 to 2017, Mossberg was Executive Editor of ''[[The Verge]]'' and Editor-at-Large of ''[[Recode]]'', web sites owned by [[Vox Media]]. Mossberg wrote a weekly column for both and also had a weekly podcast, Ctrl-Walt-Delete. Mossberg was also co-executive producer of the annual Code Conference. He retired in July 2017. Dow Jones announced on September 19, 2013, that Mossberg would leave ''The Wall Street Journal'' as part of the breakup with [[All Things Digital|AllThingsD]] by the end of the year.{{cite news |last1=Hagey |first1=Keach |last2=Launder |first2=William |date=Sep 19, 2013 |title=Tech Columnist Walt Mossberg to Leave WSJ: |url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887323308504579085663273991706 |newspaper=[[The Wall Street Journal]] }} AllThingsD was a technology conference and web site owned by Dow Jones but created and operated by Mossberg and [[Kara Swisher]]. Along with other reporters from AllThingsD, Mossberg and Swisher started a new media site called ''[[Re/code|Recode]]'' in 2014, which was acquired by [[Vox Media]] in 2015. In April 2017, Mossberg announced his plans to retire.{{cite news|last=Mossberg|first=Walt|title=Walt Mossberg is retiring in June|date=April 7, 2017|publisher=The Verge|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/4/7/15217980/walt-mossberg-retiring-in-june |accessdate=2018-04-21}} He serves on the board of [[The News Literacy Project]] and is writing a book for St. Martin’s Press. == Early life and education == {{blp unsourced section|date=April 2018}} Mossberg, a native of [[Warwick, Rhode Island]], is a graduate of [[Pilgrim High School]], [[Brandeis University]] and the [[Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism]]. ==Career== Mossberg was a reporter and editor at ''The Wall Street Journal'' from 1970 until the end of 2013. He was based in the ''Journal's'' Washington, D.C., office, where he spent 18 years covering national and international affairs before turning his attention to technology. Mossberg's ''Personal Technology'' column appeared every Thursday from 1991 through 2013. He also edited the ''Digital Solution'' column each Wednesday (authored by his colleague, [[Katherine Boehret]]), and wrote the ''Mossberg's Mailbox'' column on Thursdays. He appeared weekly on [[CNBC]], and in web videos, and was on numerous times a guest on the [[Charlie Rose (TV series)|Charlie Rose Show]],{{cite web|title=Walter Mossberg [appearances by]|publisher=[[Charlie Rose (TV series)]]|website=charlierose.com|url=https://charlierose.com/videos/30693|accessdate=2018-04-21}} airing on PBS stations. In 1999, Mossberg became the first technology writer to receive the [[Gerald Loeb Award#The Award|Loeb award for Commentary]]. In 2001, he won the World Technology Award for Media and Journalism and received an honorary Doctorate of Law from the University of Rhode Island.{{cite web|url=http://allthingsd.com/about/walt-mossberg/|title=About Us staff profile entry for Walt Mossberg|publisher=allthingsd.com|accessdate=2012-12-29}} Mossberg is widely regarded as one of the most influential writers on information technology. In 2004, in a lengthy profile, ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' called him "The Kingmaker", saying "few reviewers have held so much power to shape an industry's successes and failures."{{cite news|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]] |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/12.05/mossberg.html?pg=1 |last=Deutschman |first=Alan |title=The Kingmaker: Walt Mossberg makes or breaks products from his pundit perch at a little rag called The Wall Street Journal|date=May 2004|accessdate=2007-05-08}} A 2007 profile in the ''[[The New Yorker|New Yorker]]'' was entitled "Everyone Listens to Walter Mossberg" and declared him "someone whose judgment can ratify years of effort or sink the show."{{cite news|work=[[The New Yorker]]|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2007/05/14/critical-mass|last=Auletta|first=Ken|authorlink=Ken Auletta|title=Critical Mass: Everyone listens to Walter Mossberg|date=May 14, 2007|accessdate=2018-04-21}} In 2017, he received the Loeb Award's Lifetime Achievement Award.{{cite web|title=2017 Gerald Loeb Award Finalists, Career Achievement Honorees and Date of Awards Banquet in New York City Announced by UCLA Anderson|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/2017-gerald-loeb-award-finalists-career-achievement-honorees-and-date-of-awards-banquet-in-new-york-city-announced-by-ucla-anderson-300460104.html|website=PR Newswire|publisher=UCLA Anderson School of Management|accessdate=2018-04-21|date=May 18, 2017}} In partnership with his fellow ''Journal'' columnist [[Kara Swisher]], Mossberg created, produced and hosted the ''Journal's'' annual ''All Things Digital'' conference in [[Carlsbad, California]], in which top technology leaders, such as [[Bill Gates]], [[Steve Jobs]] and [[Elon Musk]],{{cite AV media |last=Gannes|first=Liz |title=Tesla CEO and SpaceX Founder Elon Musk: The Full D11 Interview (Video) |medium=Video interview |url=http://allthingsd.com/20130530/tesla-ceo-and-spacex-founder-elon-musk-the-full-d11-interview-video/ |accessdate=2013-05-31 |newspaper=All Things D |date=2013-05-30 }} appeared on stage without prepared remarks, or slides, and were interviewed by the two columnists.{{cite web|work=The Wall Street Journal|publisher=Dow Jones & Company|title=D: All Things Digital The Wall Street Journal Executive Conference|accessdate=2007-05-08|url=http://d.wsj.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070429142557/http://d.wsj.com/index.html|archivedate = 2007-04-29}} That conference concept continues today in the form of their Code Conference. Mossberg and Swisher also co-edited the [[All Things Digital]] web site, which included his columns, her blog and other posts. On May 30, 2007, Mossberg and Swisher conducted a historic, unrehearsed, joint onstage interview with Steve Jobs and Bill Gates.{{cite web|title=Bill Gates and Steve Jobs at D5 (Full Session)|url=http://on.wsj.com/1BvUcQu|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=July 8, 2007|accessdate=2018-04-21}} The next month, Mossberg was one of only four journalists provided with advance access to the first iPhone in order to review it.{{cite news|last=Pogue|first=David|authorlink=David Pogue|title=The 4 people Steve Jobs handpicked to review the iPhone reflect 10 years later|publisher=Yahoo Finance|date=June 25, 2017|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/pogue-levy-baig-mossberg-like-review-first-iphone-10-years-ago-132309031.html|accessdate=2018-04-21}} In September, 2013, by mutual agreement, [[Dow Jones & Co.]] and Mossberg and Swisher announced they would not renew the contract with ''AllThingsD'', and that Mossberg would be leaving ''The Wall Street Journal'' by the end of the year. On January 2, 2014, Mossberg and Swisher launched ''[[Re/code|Recode]]'', a tech website.{{cite web|work=The Next Web|publisher=Kaylene Hong|title=Re/code, a new tech website launched by Kara Swisher and Walt Mossberg, is now live|accessdate=2014-01-02|url=https://thenextweb.com/media/2014/01/02/recode-a-new-tech-website-launched-by-kara-swisher-and-walt-mossberg-is-now-live/#!rjKXS}} The website was acquired by [[Vox Media]] in May 2015 in an all-stock deal.{{cite news |title = Vox Media Adds ReCode to Its Stable of Websites |first = Sydney |last = Ember |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/27/business/media/vox-media-acquiring-recode.html?_r=0 |newspaper = [[The New York Times]] |date = May 26, 2015 |accessdate = May 27, 2015 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6YpNXfmQl?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2015/05/27/business/media/vox-media-acquiring-recode.html?_r=1 |archivedate = May 27, 2015 |deadurl = no |df = }} On April 7, 2017, Mossberg announced his planned retirement, which occurred on July 3 of that year. "It just seems like the right time to step away," Mossberg wrote in ''Recode''. "I’m ready for something new."{{cite web|last1=Mossberg|first1=Walt|title=Walt Mossberg Is Retiring in June|date=April 7, 2017|publisher=Recode|url=https://www.recode.net/2017/4/7/15211374/walt-mossberg-the-only-kingmaker-is-retiring}} His final column was published on May 25, 2017.{{cite web | url=https://www.recode.net/2017/5/25/15689094/mossberg-final-column | title=Mossberg: The Disappearing Computer | first=Walt | last=Mossberg | date=May 25, 2017 | publisher=recode.net | accessdate=May 29, 2017}} His final Code Conference was May 30–June 1, and his retirement podcast, performed live in New York, was on June 9. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://allthingsd.com/ All Things Digital] * {{C-SPAN|waltermossberg}} ** [http://www.c-span.org/video/?287793-1/qa-walt-mossberg C-SPAN ''Q&A'' interview with Mossberg, July 19, 2009] * {{Charlie Rose view|746}} * {{IMDb name|4347375}} * {{Worldcat id|lccn-no95-52569}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mossberg, Walt}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:All Things Digital people]] [[Category:American columnists]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:American technology writers]] [[Category:Brandeis University alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism alumni]] [[Category:Gerald Loeb Award winners]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Warwick, Rhode Island]] [[Category:The Wall Street Journal people]] [[Category:Writers from New York (state)]] [[Category:Writers from Rhode Island]] [[Category:Vox Media]] [[Category:Technology commentators]]

{{Icelandic name|Áslaug}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Infobox person |name=Áslaug Magnúsdóttir |image = Aslaug Magnusdottir July 2012.jpg |caption = Áslaug Magnúsdóttir 2012 |alt= Aslaug Magnusdottir |birth_name=Aslaug Magnusdottir |birth_place=[[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]] |occupation= Co-Founder of Moda Operandi, TSM Capital, Tinker Tailor |residence=New York City, New York, U.S. |alma_mater=[[University of Iceland]] ([[Candidate of Law]])

|url=http://upstart.bizjournals.com/entrepreneurs/hot-shots/2012/12/11/moda-operandi-founder-tells-her-story.html?page=all|date=December 11, 2012|publisher=The Business Journals|accessdate=April 14, |url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20120909/SMALLBIZ/309099992|date=September 9, 2012|publisher=[[Crain Communications]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} She is the co-founder{{cite news|last=Bourne|first=Leah|title=The Startup That Changed How Women Buy $10,000 Gowns|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/leahbourne/2012/02/29/the-startup-that-changed-how-women-buy-10000-gowns/ |date=February 29, 2012|publisher=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} and former{{cite news|last=Wang|first=Lisa|title=Co-Founder and CEO Áslaug Magnúsdóttir Leaves Moda Operandi|url=http://www.businessoffashion.com/2013/05/breaking-news-founder-and-ceo-aslaug-magnusdottir-leaves-moda-operandi.html |date=May 18, 2013|publisher=Business of Fashion|accessdate=May 18, 2013}} chief executive officer of [[Moda Operandi]]{{cite web|title=Aslaug Magnusdottir|url=http://www.thecoveteur.com/aslaug_magnusdottir|publisher=The Coveteur|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} and a co-founder of TSM Capital.{{cite news|last=Karimzadeh|first=Marc|title=New Traub-Led Group Invests in Williamson| url=http://www.wwd.com/beauty-industry-news/financial/new-traub-led-group-invests-in-williamson-485808?src=search_links| date=August 28, 2007|publisher=[[Women's Wear Daily]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} She has been dubbed "fashion's fairy godmother" by ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]''{{cite news|last=Barnett|first=Leisa|title=Fashion's Fairy Godmother | url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2007/09/04/fashions-fairy-godmother|date=September 4, 2007|publisher=[[Vogue (British magazine)]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} and one of the 100 Most Creative People in Business by ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]''.{{cite news| title=The 100 Most Creative People in Business 2012| url=http://www.fastcompany.com/most-creative-people/2012/aslaug-magnusdottir|date=June 2012|work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} A [[Fulbright scholar]],{{cite news|title=Bloomberg Empowered Entrpereneur |url=http://archive.bloomberglink.com/gatherings_participants_bio.php?gathering=91&Id=1709 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140715023326/http://archive.bloomberglink.com/gatherings_participants_bio.php?gathering=91&Id=1709 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 15, 2014 |date=April 14, 2011 |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]] |accessdate=April 14, 2013 }} Áslaug holds an [[MBA]] from [[Harvard Business School]],{{cite news|last=Kutz|first=Erin|title=Are Fashion Tech Startups the Latest HBS Tribe?| url= http://www.alumni.hbs.edu/enews/March2012.html|date=March 5, 2012|publisher=[[Harvard Business School]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} an [[LL.M]] from [[Duke University School of Law]]{{cite news|last=Buher|first=Bridget|title=Life's Broad Sea: Biological Conservation; Prosecuting Insider Trading; Ordering Designer Clothes | url= http://dukemagazine.duke.edu/article/lifes-broad-sea-biological-conservation-prosecuting-insider-trading-ordering-designer|date=October 2, 2012|publisher=[[Duke University]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} and a [[Candidate of Law]] degree from the [[University of Iceland]]. ==Family and education== Áslaug Magnúsdóttir was born in [[Reykjavík]], Iceland, to parents Magnús Sigurðsson and Rakel Valdimarsdóttir. She has one brother, Sigurður R. Magnússon. Áslaug grew up in Los Angeles and Reykjavík{{cite news |first=Suzanne Weinstock |last=Klein |url=https://observer.com/2014/09/aslaug-magnusdottir-on-leaving-moda-operandi-and-re-inventing-the-fashion-business/ |title=Aslaug Magnúsdóttir On Leaving Moda Operandi and Re-Inventing the Fashion Business |newspaper=[[The Observer]] |date=September 12, 2014 |accessdate=October 2, 2018 }} and attended college at the University of Iceland, where she graduated in 1993 with a degree in law.{{cite news |author=Pétur Blöndal |url=https://www.mbl.is/greinasafn/grein/1182896/ |title=Tíska er fjárfesting |newspaper=Morgunblaðið |date=December 30, 2007 |accessdate=October 2, 2018 |language=Icelandic }} She received a Fulbright scholarship and returned to the U.S. to attend the LL.M program at Duke University. She then earned an MBA from Harvard Business School in 2000, the first Icelandic woman to do so. Áslaug lives in New York with her husband Gabriel Levy.{{cite news| title=Moda Operandi takes the fashion world by storm | url=http://www.85broads.com/public/blogs/the-latest-news-from-janet-hanson/articles/moda-operandi-takes-the-fashion-world-by-storm|date=February 22, 2011|publisher=[[85 Broads]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} She was previously married to Gunnar Thoroddsen, a lawyer and former CEO of [[Landsbanki]] bank in Luxembourg.{{cite news|title=New CEO at Landsbanki Luxembourg S.A. |url=http://news.icex.is/newsservice/MMIcexNSWeb.dll/newspage?language=en&pagetype=symbolnewslist&primarylanguagecode=en&newsnumber=28767 |date=June 22, 2004 |publisher=Nordic Exchange |accessdate=October 27, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029202350/http://news.icex.is/newsservice/MMIcexNSWeb.dll/newspage?language=en&pagetype=symbolnewslist&primarylanguagecode=en&newsnumber=28767 |archivedate=October 29, 2013 }} Gunnar is the grandson of Iceland's former Prime Minister [[Gunnar Thoroddsen]], and the great grandson of Iceland's second President, [[Ásgeir Ásgeirsson]]. Together they have a son, Gunnar A. Thoroddsen. ==Career== Áslaug began her career in Iceland, where as a student she headed a modeling agency and was chairman of the National Ballet Company of Iceland, and then became a corporate and tax attorney at [[Deloitte]]. After completing her graduate studies, she moved to London, where she was an Engagement Manager at [[McKinsey & Company]]. ===Fashion career=== Áslaug first became involved in the fashion industry while helping to run a modeling agency during college. She started her professional career in fashion at [[Baugur Group]], an investment company focused on the fashion and retail sectors.{{cite news|last=Moin|first=David|title=Traub Hire Broadens Fashion Scope | url= http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-features/traub-hire-broadens-fashion-scope-512232|date=December 28, 2006|publisher=[[Women's Wear Daily]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} During her time at Baugur, Aslaug spearheaded a number of investments in early-stage fashion brands. In 2006, Áslaug relocated from London to New York and joined [[Marvin Traub|Marvin Traub Associates]] as a Vice President. In 2007, she partnered with Traub, the former CEO of [[Bloomingdale's]], to form an investment company, TSM Capital, which invested in designer brands such as [[Rachel Roy]]{{cite news|last=Karimzadeh|first=Marc |title=A New Designer Deal: TSM Capital Acquires Stake in Rachel Roy|url= http://www.wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-features/a-new-designer-deal-tsm-capital-acquires-stake-in-rachel-roy-477066?full=true |date=November 13, 2007|publisher=[[Women's Wear Daily]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} and [[Matthew Williamson]]. She later worked with actor and jewelry designer [[Waris Ahluwalia]] as President of his label, House of Waris Fine Jewelry. In 2009, Áslaug joined [[Gilt Groupe]] to head merchandising for Gilt Noir.{{cite news|last=Binkley|first=Christina|title=A Faster Trip From Runway to Shopping Cart| url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704594804575649063240286720|date=December 1, 2010|publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} In 2009, Áslaug came up with the idea for Moda Operandi, a "[[Pretail|pre-tailer]]" that lets consumers pre-order items directly from the runway.{{cite news|last=Shontell|first=Alyson|title=The Silicon Alley 100:The Coolest People in New York Tech This Year| url=http://www.businessinsider.com/sa-100-2012?op=1#ixzz2QTiKDAzx|date=October 25, 2012|publisher=[[Business Insider]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} She shared the concept with [[Lauren Santo Domingo]], and, together, they co-founded the company.{{cite news|last=Drell|first=Lauren|title=44 Female Founders Every Entrepreneur Should Know | url=http://mashable.com/2012/08/06/female-founders/|date=August 6, 2012|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=April 14, 2013}} Áslaug left Moda Operandi in May 2013 after raising $36 million from venture capital firms. With Matthew Pavelle, Gabriel Levy and Cleo Davis-Urman,{{cite news|title=The Founders|url=http://www.tinkertailor.com/about-us/|publisher=Tinker Tailor|accessdate=July 13, 2014}} she co-founded Tinker Tailor, a business that let consumers customize designer clothing or design their own.{{cite news|last=Kamm|first=Jennifer|title=Tinker Tailor Lets Users Customize Designer Dresses -- Or Design Their Own|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferkamm/2014/07/11/tinker-tailor-lets-users-customize-designer-dresses-or-design-their-own/|date=July 11, 2014|publisher=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=July 13, 2014}} Tinker Tailor ceased operations in 2015.{{cite news|last=Strugatz|first=Rachel|title=Tinker Tailor to Close|url=http://wwd.com/fashion-news/fashion-scoops/tinker-tailor-to-close-10191399/|publisher=[[Women's Wear Daily|WWD]]}} ==Awards and recognitions== * One of the BOF 500 in 2014 - ''[[The Business
